text: Implement technical safeguards for electronic protected health information (ePHI) including access controls, audit controls, integrity controls, and transmission security.
A covered entity must implement policies and procedures to limit uses and disclosures of protected health information to the minimum necessary to accomplish the intended purpose.

Following the discovery of a breach of unsecured protected health information, a covered entity shall notify each individual whose unsecured protected health information has been, or is reasonably believed to have been, accessed, acquired, used, or disclosed as a result of such breach.
Implement hardware, software, and/or procedural mechanisms that record and examine activity in information systems that contain or use electronic protected health information.
Implement procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to electronic protected health information is the one claimed.
FHIR resources represent granular clinical concepts. The most common resources are those used in clinical care, such as Patient, Practitioner, Encounter, and Observation.
FHIR APIs use a RESTful approach with JSON or XML formatting. Each resource has a known identity (a URL) that follows a predictable pattern.
FHIR security recommendations include the use of TLS/SSL for all production data exchange, OAuth2-based authorization, and digital signatures for high-value transactions.
FHIR resources should be validated against profiles that define constraints on data elements to ensure data quality and interoperability.
The FHIR Consent resource is used to capture a healthcare consumer's choices regarding policies, obligations, and permissions that may affect how data is used.
Electronic records and electronic signatures must be trustworthy, reliable, and generally equivalent to paper records and handwritten signatures.
Electronic signatures must employ at least two distinct identification components such as an identification code and password.

Consent must be freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which they, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signify agreement to the processing of personal data.

The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether or not personal data concerning him or her are being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the personal data.
The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format.
